commentBody: I like it when a Wednesday isn't a Tuesday

Thought I was tripped up on the HIRT/REO crossing, but found my mistake by misspelling WEAN (XTERRe seemed just as likely as XTERRA). 14 minutes, well above my Wednesday average, but got a full month on my streak now
Tricky for a Wednesday! Not a bad thing at all. This felt a little "old school" to me in a way I have trouble articulating. Still accessible enough to solve trickier clues with crosses.

As a self described connoisseur of breakfast cereal I enjoyed this grainy puzzle.  I thought using three cereals with X in their names was a pretty nifty trick.  I shudder to think how many bowls of sugary and heavily dyed Trix I ate as a child.  Kix on the other hand are still somewhat palatable, and Chex are quite decent.

Seeing Al HIRT in the puzzle took me back to the sixties.  HIRT and Herb Alpert formed pretty much my sole experience of jazz until I got to college, fell in with a hip crowd, and discovered Miles and Coltrane et al.  That changed my musical world for good.
Quite a test of brand awareness.

Slower than average but also I have a migraine so that's not a reflection of the puzzle!

I had lift before TBAR, which changed pretty quickly when I  hit 27D, where I had pAl before MAn before MAC (and it took me way too long to parse AnESUP, to the point that i considered a box of trix instead of a bag, which would give onESUP but also GREGx. 

Anyway I suggest not dealing with a migraine when trying to crossword....

X marks the spot.

Love me some CHEX mix, but never cared much
for KIX or TRIX. Still a fun puzzle.

When I was doing this puzzle, cheating as I went, I swore some of these clues are Saturday level misdirection!  Now that I've struggled through it, amassing eight cheats, I can recognize its cleverness.  I never eat those cereals, and wouldn't, even if there were gluten free versions.  But I did recognize most of the brands.  Having finished, I will amend my judgment to say this is a Thursday level puzzle!  The streak goes on...

A bit of a toughie, but DEF doable. Spent 4 minutes flyspecking to find my error and just decided to try a C and change MAn to MAC, which did the trick.

Well, it's been decades since I've eaten any of those except CHEX, but I still see them whenever I go down the CEREAL AISLES, so they're familiar names. And there was part of an old favorite—GRAPE Nuts—included. I'm kinda surprised that we didn't have the crossword's favorite cereal: Oreo-Os.

Well, that's Life, and I'd better say Cheerio!

Thanks, Kathy, it was delicious.
Very tricky one for international solvers. I'm not complaining, as I enjoy the challenge and learning about other cultures, but it was definitely over my Wednesday average.

Shakes fist at 9D, "calculus expert".

That killed my gold star. On a Wednesday!

As someone who isn't from America, I really struggled with this one. TOTAL, AKRON, USTEN, AFLCIO, and all the cereal brands really made it a challenge for me. I'm just glad the constructor didn't throw in any senators or judges into the mix, it would have been very painful for me.

"You were supposed to go cereal shopping with me!"
"Sorry, I've been flakey lately."

("No worries! Tomorrow is a bran new day.")
Can we all agree - most difficult Wednesday of the year? What an absolute beast 😅
It's good that they publish the really bad ones. Makes you appreciate the good ones.
Tricky! Loved it. Thanks!

Whew! 😅 Toughest Wednesday in quite a while. My kids don’t like any of these CEREALs, but I definitely recognized every one of them. I appreciated the cleverness of using the ending X in each cereal to create the common phrases. You have a great sense of HUMOR, Kathy Bloomer 😜 Thank you for the eXtra challenge today 💪🏼
Maybe a few too many crosswordisms… but I still got in under my Wednesday average and I rarely eat cereal.
Considering it’s impossible to buy a half bag of TRIX, I’m not sure I love the “bulk” cluing.

That was a rough one. Not sure why some constant (and short!) crossword answers just refuse to stick in my brain, like the city where the Taj Mahal is and the other way to get up a ski slope when you have trouble with the lift.

Listening to the Warriors game while I solved and thought my serial mistakes were from all the distraction.  I was in a TOTAL jam and thought I was toast, but I stopped STUing and the WHOLE BAG OF TRIX sTARTed to HANG together. Sometimes when one fACES UP to a challenge everything turns out OKAY.

Thank you Kathy.  A great way for GETTING ONE's KIX on a Tuesday night. 

  (Srsly!)

Wednesday puzzles are my favorite, and this one was crunchy-as-cereal and more challenging than usual. The foibles that held me up were "absurd" instead of ONE ACT for [Like Ionesco's play "The Bald Soprano"] and "soul" instead of CRUX for [Essence.] There was, overall, much in this puzzle that I had to get from crosses, but I had a good time. Thank you, Ms. Bloomer! (My song for today is Alan Parsons' "Old and WISE" https://youtu.be/Ow3cDKwIiMg?si=UdPie-_40p3pGkrz)
It took me a while to get that Special Kea in 16A.
Was this a sponsored post??? Way too many brand names

Agreeing with most commenters so far... this one took significantly longer than my Wednesday average. Nice to have a crunchier one, which is appropriate for the theme.

Having had many deep cleanings in my life, 9D DDS was practically a gimme. The Natick for me in that section was 6D and 18A. Had no idea what Flying Cloud and Royale were, and hadn't heard of the trumpeter. Luckily, this was my last open square (after flyspecking to change MAn to MAC and realizing I had a typo in ETRE, so I ran the alphabet for HIRT/REO and got the happy music (but only in my head because I have the sound turned off.)

PTUI was also a gimme, but I couldn't tell you why.

Nice to see SEDER in there during Passover.

No lookups but definitely used all of the crosses.
For those who found this a tough Wednesday crossword, maybe it might be best described as a cereal killer.  🤪
Was this crossword sponsored by General Mills?

I was going to say, give me my good old homemade muesli - 
but then I googled, and what do you know, there is a thing in the CEREAL AISLE called MUESLIX!

For you word people: why do they think the final x makes a fun brand name?

Let’s try it out:
EGGNOX
FROGLEX
UGLIX
GRAPEX

Hmm, not convinced.

Not the biggest fan of heavy-handed use of brand names in this one.  
I liked the misdirection in some of the clues, though, and have to admit that it was a clever puzzle.

This was impossibly hard not only for me but also for my wickedly smart wife. This has never happened before. When I struggle, I will sometimes hand my phone to the Wife, and she does in minutes what has been stumping me for half an hour. Not today though. Just wow.

All the names, brands, abbreviations... It's like the grid was designed to frustrate me. 

The area directly North was especially nasty, with a name and brands crossing.

I haven't enjoyed a puzzle as little as this in a long time.

Also, PTUI...

I feel like taking a break from NYT grids after this.
I would be shocked if anyone anywhere got HIRT/REOS/DDS without cheating. Poor editing there.
This one felt like it was made by an alien. Most answers were strange and off beat. 2/10
That's a lotta proper nouns. Befitting of a themed Thursday perhaps, but what a wonderful balance of forgiving grid layout and tricky clues. Great puzzle!

Crossword puzzles are usually a fun way to challenge myself and learn something new, but this one was disappointing. The overuse of brand names, proper nouns, and slang (colloquialisms) made it feel more like a trivia test than an enriching word game. I would’ve appreciated a better balance, ideally with a few fresh or thought-provoking words and phrases to walk away with.

Suspect this was a tough Wednesday puzzle for those who live in North America and nigh on impossible for the rest of the world.   No criticism of the constructor; on the other hand,  the editors would do well  to remember that their audience is indeed global - or at least that’s what management hopes for !

From someone living on the other side of the world, the theme is near-impossible to solve without looking up the brands and certain proper nouns. 

The clues about a baseball team, a General Mills brand, a razor brand, a shampoo brand, an American labor union, an American highway, the two clues about skiing, and American cereal brands are just...bad.

0/10

Re 21A, a quick survey of Wikipedia let's me know that Kix and Trix were introduced by General Mills, which bought Chex in '97.

In the 80s I would go to my grandparents after school, have some Rice Chex for a snack, and watch M*A*S*H reruns with grandad. Good memories.
Kind of lame to build an entire theme around made up brand names…

Well, that one definitely passed the breakfast test, although FROG LEGS almost made me want to PTUI. A lot of negative comments today, but I for one rather enjoyed the unusual entries and challenging clues. I agree it would be tough for a non-North American.
No fun at all. Didn't even want to finish, which is a first for me. Far too exclusive...
Didn't bother trying to finish this one, for many of the reasons already listed by other international commenters. Not sure how this one got through editing but here we are.

Started off well but quickly lost interest as the proper nouns stacked up. Having never heard of REOS, TOTAL, Al HIRT, ACES UP, TBAR, GREGG Popovich, ATRA, AFLCIO, AFRAMES, XTERRA, CHEX, KEX, DDS, AKRON and OSTER made this particular rough going.
Almost want to cancel my subscription when we get this sort of meaningless brand name salad

Whew! Feeling like I should toss a positive comment in here. That was a little extra tough but fun. I enjoyed the cereal puns, they were cute. I definitely learned a few new things and came in well over my Wednesday time but I made it through with no help. Which is exactly what I want on a Wednesday. My last square was the R in HIRT and that was just a good guess. Overall fair game, if maybe a little more low culture than the usual highbrow ( though we still got our requisite ALP and a healthy dose of skiing trivia). Thumbs up.

I look forward to reading comments, especially because the international solvers weigh in early and provide a fun perspective. Today was no exception! I thought about the cereal brands and how tough that would be for non-Americans, plus a lot of names and places. Some days you're the pigeon, some days you're the statue. 

As an Ohioan, I had to laugh when AKRON Rubber Ducks revealed itself. As a sports ignoramus, I didn't know the team, but Akron is known as Rubber City, because it is the rubber capital of the world!

Really disliked this one. I got the themers somehow (brand names, but also puns, so acceptable in my book), but the top central part was just awful. Brand next to brand next to brand (OSTER, REOS, TOTAL - even that could not be clued differently??). And the completely mysterious DDS, which made me doubt HOWD (and my life choices, as somebody who also teaches calculus for a living). I ended up doing a double alphabet run: all vowels for _STER, and all letters for HIR_, and this worked only because Flying Cloud and Royale kind of sound like something that could be cars, so R seemed the most reasonable guess for _EOS.

My streak is fortunately intact, but my Wednesday average probably went up by several minutes.
Never has a puzzle felt more exclusive than this one. There’s nothing here for me, better luck tomorrow, I guess.

I understand why non-US solvers struggled with this one, but I’m surprised so many in the States were stumped as well. Maybe I just spend too much time in the grocery store!

Aside from that REO_/DD_ stickler (which eventually came to me but it took a while), I didn’t find anything too difficult. Is Al Hirt really that obscure? There were several clues with multiple possible answers, so I had to do a lot of back-and-forth correction, but I enjoyed the process. I guess you could say I like to milk my cereal puzzles.

In spite of the fact that I've never been a cereal fan, I really liked this theme. All common expressions ending with a homophone of a cereal brand and all ending in X. Even if you don't know the brand, as long as you know the expression, you're all set. Nice find, Kathy. Then there was Nelson's Blood: https://youtu.be/gZDgV-Cqle8?si=8JwHU_x6y1RH-sR4

As others have indicated, pretty inaccessible for some of us. For me, the razor was the worst. I finished with some reveals. Lots of good clues too.
Please help - DDS?
This puzzle was wretched and PTUI is the single most forced entry I've ever encountered. And that's not even the clue I gave up on. So many nouns and naticks, just a slog
Quite a few Trix, but after some Chex it came together. As a kid I got my Kix listening to Al Hirt play the Green Hornet's theme song (and REO Speedwagon, of course).
I kind of wish I had avoided reading the comments today. The number of complaints about the prevalence of American-specific answers in a crossword produced in America became tiresome.

This was a delightful puzzle. For me it hit the sweet spot - not so easy that I whipped through it, but not so hard that I needed to start googling. I caught onto the theme towards the end, which is always the most fun. The little section with solitaire and razors nearly did me in, but I guessed UP and all was well. Great fun!

Whew, this Wednesday almost got me! Extremely challenging (for me) but ultimately a great workout.

"HIM OR" me before "HUMOR" me, "RTTEN" before "USTEN", "CASE" before "COST" ... and got DDS fully from crosses.

Chewy and clever, and thank goodness for the "X" theme or I'd have never gotten Xterra.

Happy post tax day and hope it's sunny where you are! Boston's been glorious the last two days. ☀️

I am sorry folks but todays cross word was NOT GOOD. Too many bloody american-isms for old Bridget's liking. Reminds me a lot of the, now infamous in Ireland, Terry Veg crossword from a few months back. Scandalous that was. Either way i hope you all have a grand day. 

Bridget O'Doole

Oh dear.
I make a point of not being a negative Nellie when it comes to crosswords, particularly in a (for me) foreign publication. I pays me money, I takes me choice.

So, happy for all who enjoyed it, for all those who found it chewy but doable. Utterly impossible for none American me without Google and Wordplay, ergo not a great solve. Hey ho.

Onwards and upwards.

Yuck. I never like clues where I can tell the creator worked backwards to find meanings for a random bunch of letters, and this one was studded with them.

I don't get to do the crossword often enough to have streaks or averages. This one definitely would've wrecked all that, so for once I'm glad for my lack of free time.

I had MAn instead of MAC. I'm not familiar with that particular form of solitaire, either, and I was thinking of high cards as being kings, not aces, as they are in some games. I gave up and looked up the answer. Maybe if I'd persevered I could have gotten the final letter.

Part of the problem was that I was convinced MAn was correct, and that my mistake was elsewhere. But I'm still grabbing that ill-gotten gold star and running off with it.
Pretty trixie for a Wednesday. Thanx Kathy My song of the day, Get Your Kix on Route Sixty-six.. https://youtu.be/uRX_NZ7kTt0?si=IW0OMTdYgo8KBJF7

Like the other non-USAns, I found this a beast, though not because of the theme entries, which were deducible. After filling the grid, the entries I had to fix were MAN, ONESUP, WHOLEBOX..., GEEGX, ESTEE (nicely clued by "Big name in blenders"), TEBAL, HERB (thinking of Alpert, having misread the clue) and ENHD.
So, not much fun for me, but I have no complaints about a US crossword being US-centric.
This crossword was so American it deserves a reciprocal tariff

Tough one for me and had to cheat a bit in a couple of places but managed to slog my way through. Catching on to the trick was a nice moment and that's always a good touch. 

And... a couple of interesting (and appropriate) puzzle finds. First a Wednesday from January 14, 1998 by William Bernhardt. Three theme answers in that one:

TRIXOFTHETRADE
CHEXANDBALANCES
KIXUPONESHEELS

And then a Thursday from February 20, 2003 by Peter Sarrett. Three theme answers in that one: 

TRIXOFTHETRADE
CHEXOUTOFREHAB
KIXITUPANOTCH

Hmmmm..... 

I'm done. 

.....

Took me a while to figure out what the theme gimmick was – that the letter X sounds like CKS, in a cereal name context.  That was one of the things I really liked about this puzzle, that there was a Riddle I had to work for a while at to crack.  My brain loves to dig dig dig and revels when it uncovers the treasure.

Along the way, I kept encountering lovely things:
•	GRU over STU.
•	GRU touching STEW.
•	ALP up high.
•	PER, the first name of yesterday’s constructor, in the grid.
•	The old crossword friend [Mauna ___].
•	A pair of is-it-a-noun-or-verb clues in [Craving] and [Damage, so to speak].
•	A slew of answers that can be nouns or verbs – DOG, STEW, SCRAP, TOTAL, HUMOR, GREASE, DYES, URGE, PANTS, PASS.

So, with the rub and loveliness, you brought me a splendid outing, Kathy, for which I’m most grateful.  Thank you!

Hilariously, PTUI was one of very few gimmes for me in this grid.

FROGLEGS came late---I'm more used to the possessive than the noun modifier. But I've certainly eaten more frogs' legs in the last half century than I have breakfast cereal, let alone breakfast cereals ending in X.

I have a question about SCRAP clued as [Doggie bag morsel]. I hate restaurants that offer more food than I want, and so find doggie bags a vaguely nauseating idea. But in these parts a food "scrap" is pretty much the antithesis of a "morsel"---the latter is something inviting you'd pop in your mouth; the former is something you scrape off your plate into your compost recycling bin (or perhaps offer to an actual dog).
Am I missing some subtlety of usage, here, or is this just one of those things that works better as a crossword clue than in real life?

Strands! No spoilers, please, before "view all replies"

Strands #409
“Fore!”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵

Easy-peasy even though it's not my thing.
Dr. Bloomer's 4th puzzle since 2018 with an Xcellent and entertaining theme.  Well done and many thanks.
Very fun theme but this was far, far more difficult than a normal Wednesday for me. Pretty sure I used hints/cheats for a full third of the puzzle.

Alas, poor Sam's solving demise at the hands of Dr. Bloomer!

Mystery solved: This puzzle was a CEREAL KILLER.

This was a whole-brain puzzle.

(Personally, no Natix, but I can see them from here.)

I just loved this puzzle, but as I did it, I thought to myself, "Oh, wow, non-Americans are going to find this a tough one." As a baby-boomer, I find most clues that have to do with movies, songs, rock stars etc. of the 21st century tough. I don't complain.

I believe producer (and later, Sir) George Martin is more often considered the "Fifth Beatle" for his profound contributions to their sound, and their general well-being.
Stu Sutcliff was never the fifth. When he was playing with the lads, the combo was a quartet, and Sir George was still well off in their future.

Fun! 

X is a fun letter, and sure did
make this one a speedier solve.

Had MAn, not MAC, so I got an extra minute 
to play!

In my head, I’d never want to
eat those cereals.
But I’ve  got a sneaking suspicion,
if you put a bowl in front of me,
I’d down it and want seconds.

Life was simpler when a bowl of cold, sugary
cereal counted as a meal.
*sigh*

I want that back.

Nice one! 

Happy hump day all!

Really enjoyed the whole puzzle... except for that top center that resisted any entry. Needing HIRT and DDS is a big ask. I ended up looking up trumpeter Al and it all fell in to place, though I still didn't get DDS until reading Wordplay. That's a really sneaky one that I secretly kind of love.

Along with others, I thought this puzzle and theme was almost impossible to solve without knowing some seemingly very obscure Americanisms. REOS, ROID, ATRA, AFLCIO, XTERRA, USTEN, TGEL, DDS and OSTER mean absolutely nothing to me.

I thought the theme was interesting and well-composed once I’d revealed it but was entirely inaccessible to me as we don’t have these brands in the U.K., nor am I familiar with them at all. I understand this is an American paper and this is what I pay for, but I would like to see some more internationally friendly clues to give those solving outside of the U.S. a fair chance at solving.

Not that I'e ever been to a ski resort, but I knew enough to slap CHALETS into the grid at 48A.... and then take it out and put in LODGES....Grrr  

Too bad there aren't more CEREALs that end in X, eh?  Kathy Bloomer nearly turned out a puzzle that didn't have a cartoon movie, a sports coach, and a car model sullying the array of clues...  CLOSE, BUT NO CIGAR.  (I forgive the minor league team because AKRON has a sense of history and a sense of HUMOR, plus Ohio, where I spent 9 + 14 years of my life.)

Really fun puzzle!  Must run....POOF!

I thought the constructor/editors missed an opportunity in cluing 23-D to justify the unusual placement of the themed answers.

It could have read, "Places to go *down* to find..."

Of course, the puzzle doesn't really require any such "justification."
Good, tough puzzle with a nice theme!
Well it took a while, but I liked PTUI when I got it.

I read through *almost* all the comments and didn’t see any mention that USTEN does not go to Seattle at all! Ends in North Dakota. Interstate 90 ends in Seattle (but I believe it starts in Boston). I mean….???

One may be hard pressed to find a TBAR on the slopes, but what the heck, this is just a puzzle.

We took the cereal boxes and made barriers so we would not need to see our siblings as we breakfasted.

Fun Wednesday although PTUI took some whiles.

Thank you Kathy

I fear an aspect of this wonderfully clever theme has not been adequately lauded in the comments I've scanned. From Sam in her column:

"It’s not the [Places to find the items at the ends of 4-, 8- and 14D] that you should pay attention to, but the phrases in which they appear, because that’s where the wit of this theme really shines." 

Leave the CEREAL AISLE behind and behold the puns! I finally saw it with WHOLE BAG OF TRIcks, and then revisited the other two. Sweet! 

Also sneaking in another cereal with TOTAL. Also sneaking in another pun at 40D. And I appreciate that (most of) the crosses at X are real words: no easy task, I'd imagine, with that letter in particular! 

LIFT before TRAM before that ole throwback, the crossword go-to T-BAR. Oh well. 

Loved PTUI!! (Though I really want an E on the end...) Can't you just hear it hitting that spittoon? I'll have to try and work it into conversation today.  :)

PTUI! This puzzle took more than double my best time, and about 6.30 more than my average time. Somehow I solved every last clue, but my cereal got very soggy in the meantime. I see I'm not the only one who was eating mush. My sympathies to everyone outside the USA, and to many herein.
Wow! Another difficult one for a Wednesday. What a hard week so far. Scared for tomorrow 😅

A remarkably unenjoyable puzzle. Full of non-universal brands (cereals aside, how is ATRA meant to resonate?) some incredibly obscure words (PTUI is not cute) and mean spiritedly obtuse clues (who is associating DDS with calculus?). I'm all for a challenge but this is like a murder mystery where the killer is revealed despite no evidence or clues being present prior.

Mon-Thurs puzzle bad
Fri and Sat puzzle good

I always keep an Atra in my murse in case I need to shave my frog legs. In case you were wondering, murse is not an acceptable word in Wordle. Can anyone hear "bag of tricks" and not think of Felix the Cat?: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L52GLlJFNuE Seems like just yesterday me and Abe Vigoda were watching cartoons when we got home from kindergarten.
What an accomplishment to have your puzzle featured in the NY Times, and what a bummer to come to the comment section to learn everyone hated it. I thought it was great!
Tough one. Didn't think it was as bad as other commenters but I had to refer to the column to preserve my streak.

Remarkably fun puzzle to me, though not a gimme by any stretch (couldn’t 18A’s clue have included “Speedwagon”? lol).  Two things made it interesting to me: that third level of clever by incorporating puns into the long, themed answers; and the fact that nothing in the puzzle was impossible for normal people and certainly not for dedicated crossworders.  I usually get stumped by pop culture or sports names and there was only one of those in the middle.
Lift instead of TBAR, chalets instead of AFRAMES, not to mention all the cereal brands... this was a tough one that had me checking to make sure it was still Wednesday.
Delightful puzzle!  “Fella” stumped me for a while and I’m not familiar with that solitaire game, at least by that name. Harder than a typical Wednesday, but so fun!

20 proper nouns, not to mention the additional slang sprinkled throughout. i don't understand why the nytxw continues to move in this direction. trivia already exists.
just a truly horrible puzzle. this is not enjoyable.
Got tripped up by the cross of the trumpeter and the  Flying Cloud/Royale, hadn’t heard of either. Fun theme though!
Glad to know I am not the only one who found this one a little frustrating lol

My original comment from an hour ago never appeared, to add insult to injury. Got naticked with HIRT and REOS. Would have been more fair if REOS was clued as “Certain Speedwagons.” Wasn’t a fan of this puzz, it was a (cereal) killer. I liked yesterday’s cigar puzzle a lot more.

Two fun facts inspired by today's puzzle:

CEREAL derives from the adjective form of the Roman Goddess Ceres, goddess of agriculture.  She is often depicted carrying a sheaf of grain.

"Kintsugi" is the name of the art form associated with the picture in today's "Wordplay" column.  It involves repairing broken pottery with a mixture of lacquer and gold, resulting in a work more beautiful than the original piece.  
Such a nice metaphor for life!
Ack. A lot of lookups and abbreviations I didn’t know. At least my old pal UGLI is here.

I agree this was a tough Wednesday puzzle. To all the comments about HIRT, REOS and TBAR: these are frequent fill in the NYT crossword. File them away in your memory for next time. The only reason I have known a Greek marketplace is an AGORA for over 40 years thanks to the crossword.

A “fella” is MAC?
You know you can just have clues that work, right?

This was a struggle, especially the top-middle. Got multi-naticked by TOTAL-OSTER-HIRT-REOS, still not sure what DDS are, didn't get WHOLE from the clue because typically a bulk purchase is not just a whole bag, no? I can see the thematic incentive to clue TOTAL that way, but it doesn't even have a hyperlink on the General Mills Wikipedia page. Ask me how I know that. Ha ha.

However, quite proud of myself for guessing AKRON with only one crossing because I knew Mauna KEA, and I knew MAC from the other day. And I always enjoy seeing a lot of X in an Xword.

I enjoyed this Wednesday challenge Kathy! Have not been consistent enough throughout the decades to know AL HIRT and REOS as gimmes but really glad to learn of these things! 

Sam encouraged me to go do more work than I had so I fixed GRAtE to GRAPE and tTUI to PTUI and thanks for the Merriam Webster Scrabble Finder app, Sam. That is really very cool! Would be a cheat in the game but good for practice!

I suddenly remembered TOTAL although haven’t eaten most of these cereals in decades but this was fun.

Also took me a moment to get XTERRA but re: REO: I think I’m better at cars I’ve seen in the last 10 or 20 years just on the road. Still I think my grandparents had an Oldsmobile. Going through
the alphabet on R of REO just didn’t think it was a thing. How fast we forget!

Oof, not a fan of this one. The whole grid was full of naticks for me (if I’m using that word right?), and while I appreciate the need for brand names in the theme, there were way more than I would have liked in the non-theme sections too. If this had been a Friday, at least I would have felt like it was my fault for not getting it…
Actually I thought it was a hard but fair grid. At first I thought it might be trouble, but ended up solving it in under 40 minutes with (unlike yesterday) no look ups.
This puzz was to hard
This fill is awful throughout.

I'm on the pro side on this one, though I needed the column to get the north central.
   When am I going to remember how likely HD is to pop up?
  When am I going to remember REO? And GTE too, or is it GTO?
 OTOH, I  got AKRON right away because, like  @Geoff, @Steve L, @Mean Old Lady, @Nora and @Niki B, I know they make tires there. I put this down to a 7th grade social studies teacher who expected us to know the principal products of something like 40 New York state cities. (Back when we manufactured things in the US.) I only remember Elmira for milk bottles, but one of the other products was clothespins.

HUMOR me, choregi

Don't STU if your EXES ENDORSEDCHEX ISLATE. 
PTUI PTUI! to EVIL thoughts...
Like ...May my ex, GREGG AKRON and his new ONEACT play,  "ETRE FROGLEGS" fail.
So, he didn't even cast you as an EXTERRA, and he's in the lead?
Be WISE, and PASS on the URGE to HANG out in the foyer in your APESUIT, or no PANTS, with your petite mutt ATRA (desc. sire The Thin Man terrier).
A SCHEMER ought not to mix GETTINGONESKIX with RUM, he should be GOVERNED by a MUTED SLEDGE.  
Alas, too much of the TART GRAPE, ergo an UGLI SCRAP at any COST?

Tomorrow's Page Six:

For anyone who doesn’t recognize it, the work in the column photo is an example of the art of kintsugi.

I learned about this Japanese art form when I went to the Carolinas for the solar eclipse in 2017 (was it really so long ago? - time flies faster as we go along). I stayed at the home of a couple who were both artists, the husband in woodwork, the wife mostly in cloth and fabric work, but she had then gotten deep into kintsugi and made some marvelous pieces.

It is a worthy rabbit hole to look into.

Lots of people in these comments like to think about whether puzzles are objectively easier or harder than they used to be.

It's obviously a somewhat (very?) endogenous issue since we get better at puzzles the more we do them.

But I have a different question. What is the optimal age for a crossword puzzler? I ask because some of my favorite posters have revealed themselves to be 70, 75, 80, even 90! 

Is there a sweet spot at which current knowledge/trivia is still accessible but you're senior enough to remember old stuff (maybe trivia, maybe things you learned in various levels of school?) What about if you have kids? (I know having teens makes me more aware of current trivia, etc.)

I'm 56 for the record, and feel kind of close to the sweet spot! (I'm slow as can be, to be sure, but I can *usually* solve unaided).

Thoughts?

Looking a little deeper, it seems all these cereals were invented by General Mills in the '50s. It seems General Mills had a whole bag of tricks. ATRA also stands for Advanced Technology Reconnaisance Aircraft. General Mills had an electronics and aviation division that is known for their high altitude balloons designed to surveil the Soviet Bloc and China in the 1950's. The name of this was Project Genetrix. (you can't make this stuff up) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Genetrix A series of 516 spy ballons were released from multiple launch sites in the US and Europe, much to the dismay of the Russian GRU. This was a precursor to Lockheed's Project Dragon Lady, the U-2 spy plane which was still on the drawing board. The U-2 was operated by the CIA. https://www.lockheedmartin.com/en-us/products/u2-dragon-lady.html The Dragon Lady in DC circles was Anna Chennault, widow of famed Flying Tiger volunteer group in China, Claire Chennault. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Chennault Nixon, Howard Hughes, Anna Chennault, The CIA, Johnson, Kennedy, makes for an interesting read.

@Beth
OK, thanks.
So we seem to have different operational definitions of SCRAP. 
Hereabouts, at least, while "scraps" can be the remains of a meal, there's a negative connotation---you might scavenge for scraps of food if you were ravenously hungry, but they're not something you'd take home for later.
"Morsels", on the other hand, are something you do routinely eat, and sometimes even as a treat, if they're "tasty morsels" or "choice morsels".

No such thing as "tasty scraps" or "choice scraps", though.

@Grant
Smaller portion sizes mean that there's less leftover food in European restaurants, and if you signal that you're finished while there's still food on your plate, in many places you'll be asked what it was you didn't like, rather than be offered a bag to lug it home in.
That said, there's still a lot of food waste in restaurants, so France, for one, has now made it a legal requirement for establishments to make doggie bags available, if a patron asks for one. It needs a bit of a cultural change, though, since there is a degree of stigma associated with asking to take the remains of a carefully prepared meal home in a bag to reheat---you're seen as undervaluing the work of perfectly timed preparation and plating, somewhat.

In pizza and tapas places in the UK, thougb, where more food is served than many people want to eat, a doggie bag is often offered if there's food left. My SIL routinely orders enough pizza for two meals, and talks half of it home, for instance.

Personally, I just never go back to places that serve massive portions---my appetite deserts me as soon as a heaped plate lands in front of me. It used to be a major problem in Alaska, where even a cinnamon bun with coffee would turn out to be larger than my head.

Regarding the question of whether puzzles these days are easier or harder, I started solving in 2021 and have been working backward through the archives at the same time I solve new puzzles.  I'm though most of 2013, and here's a comparison by day of how my average 2013 times stack up against 2025:
Monday +6%
Tuesday +16%
Wednesday +15%
Thursday +44%
Friday +109%
Saturday +97%
Sunday +55%

In all cases my times are slower in 2013 than 2025 even though I would have been working the 2013 and 2025 puzzles during the same time period, so the "getting better over time" argument doesn't apply.  I think some of the difference is because puzzles reference current events, lingo, etc. which are easier to get in the moment.  However, I think that's only a minor part of the increase.

I'm just one data point, but for me the older puzzles are definitely harder!

This is a great question. I'm 60 (one of the oldest GenXers), and feel like I'm the right age for most of it. I've lived long enough to pick up a lot of knowledge that my brain surprises me with while solving. Ja Rule (a few days ago), where did that come from? 

But I also keep up with pop culture (don't have kids so it's not as easy for me as for my siblings). In fact, I'm doing the album-a-day challenge this year and feeling really excited by some of the newer artists. (Looking at you, Chappell Roan.)

My weakest area is sports, and that's not age-related. 

I also think that the more you solve, no matter what your age is, the better you get. I watched the Wordplay documentary a few weeks ago and was very impressed by the 20-year-old guy who won the American crossword tournament. Wow.

As for this current puzzle, I didn't grow up eating any of those cereals, but I saw all the commercials for them and have been to a grocery store. I finished the puzzle without lookups, but there were quite a few answers I had to guess and figure out using logic. That's what you learn the more you solve.

@Niki B.  Late response, but in addition to age,  a large factor is also who is in one’s social circles.   We’re lucky to have a fair bit of millennial and Gen Z interaction through our children, neighbors and volunteer work.
